By Sarah N. Lynch
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Former Democratic presidential candidate Senator Bernie Sanders said Sunday he would have preferred to see Hillary Clinton select someone like Senator Elizabeth Warren for the vice presidential spot over Senator Tim Kaine.""I have known Tim Kaine for a number of years...Tim is a very
column2: very smart guy. He is very nice guy
column3: Sanders said on NBC's ""Meet the Press.""

column1: He is more conservative than I am. Would I have preferred to see somebody like an Elizabeth Warren selected by Secretary Clinton? Yes
column2: I would have.""

column1: (Reporting by Sarah N. Lynch; editing by Mark Heinrich)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-vicepresident-idUSKCN1021JF	Democrat Clinton picks Kaine as running mate
column2: bypassing liberals	"

column1: By John Whitesides and Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON/TAMPA
column2: Fla.

column1: WASHINGTON/TAMPA
column2: Fla. Hillary Clinton named U.S. Senator Tim Kaine as her running mate on Friday
column3: opting for an experienced governing partner who will help her present the Democratic ticket as a steady alternative to the unpredictable campaign of Republican presidential rival Donald Trump.The selection of Kaine
column4: a self-described ""boring"" Virginian with a reputation for low-key competence
column5: could appeal to independents and moderates
column6: but it quickly angered liberal groups that object to his advocacy for an Asian free-trade pact.The Spanish-speaking former Virginia governor and Richmond mayor fit Clinton's long-stated criteria that the vice presidential choice be a capable and reliable partner who is ready to take over the presidency if necessary.Clinton made the announcement via Twitter and a text message to supporters after the first day of a two-day campaign swing in Florida. She called Kaine to tell him about 40 minutes before the announcement
column7: and called President Barack Obama shortly after Kaine.""I'm thrilled to tell you this first: I've chosen Sen. Tim Kaine as my running mate. Welcome him to my team
column8: she said in her text message.Kaine
column10: edged out two other finalists - Cory Booker
column11: a U.S. senator from New Jersey
column13: according to a Democratic source familiar with the discussions.Clinton also bypassed candidates who would have generated more excitement among liberal and Hispanic activists
column14: including progressive favorite U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren and two Hispanic members of Obama's Cabinet
column15: Julian Castro and Thomas Perez.The former secretary of state will be formally nominated as the party's presidential candidate for the Nov. 8 election at next week's Democratic convention in Philadelphia. She leads Trump in many opinion polls.Clinton's choice of a running mate could give her campaign momentum heading into the convention
column16: as the fight for the White House begins a more than three-month push to the finish.            Clinton
column18: acknowledged in an interview earlier this week that even Kaine admits he is boring
column19: and said she did not mind.""I love that about him
column20: she told Charlie Rose of CBS News and PBS. ""He's never lost an election. He was a world-class mayor
column21: governor and senator and is one of the most highly respected senators I know.""A campaign official said Clinton was impressed with Kaine's down-to-earth style when she campaigned with him in Virginia last week. Afterwards
column22: Kaine went back to her house in Washington
column24: for a 90-minute evening meeting.Two days later
column27: joined Clinton in New York for lunch
column30: daughter Chelsea and Chelsea's husband. Kaine was the only vice presidential candidate to have a private family lunch during the vetting process

column1: GLAD TO SEE THEM""
Clinton's campaign chairman
column2: John Podesta
column3: who led the search
column4: offered her advice. ""It needs to be someone who whenever they walk into a room you are glad to see them and want to have them as part of any conversation
column5: the campaign official quoted Podesta telling her.Kaine's first appearance with Clinton will be on Saturday at an event in Miami
column6: a campaign aide said.""Just got off the phone with Hillary. I'm honored to be her running mate. Can't wait to hit the trail tomorrow in Miami
column7: Kaine said on Twitter.Liberal groups
column8: which had pressured Clinton not to pick Kaine because of his support for fast-track authority for the White House to negotiate the Trans-Pacific Partnership

column1: Critics of the Asia free-trade deal
column2: including Trump and Clinton's Democratic primary rival Bernie Sanders
column3: say it would be unfair to U.S. workers and kill jobs. Clinton praised the deal when she was secretary of state
column4: but has since distanced herself from it.""Republicans will run hard against Democrats on trade this year. Unfortunately
column5: since Tim Kaine voted to fast-track the Trans-Pacific Partnership
column6: Republicans now have a new opening to attack Democrats on this economic populist issue
column7: said Stephanie Taylor
column8: co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee.Hispanic activists also may be annoyed with the pick of Kaine given that Latino candidates were again passed over
column9: though some Latino advocacy groups praised the choice.""She has chosen a running mate that has a track record of advocating and fighting for the issues that affect the Latino community and our nation: immigration
column13: executive director of Mi Familia Vota. Top Republicans were quick to criticize Clinton's choice.The Trump campaign called Kaine ""an ethically challenged insider"" and called Clinton and Kaine a ""Status Quo"" ticket. ""If you think Crooked Hillary and Corrupt Kaine are going to change anything in Washington
column15: campaign aide Jason Miller said in a statement.Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus condemned the pick
column16: saying Clinton spent the past week pandering to Sanders and grassroots Democrats
column17: and now ""has chosen someone who holds positions that she's spent the entire primary trying to get to the left of.""

column1: But Republican Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona
column2: who has been critical of Trump
column3: said on Twitter that he was trying to count the ways he hated Tim Kaine. ""Drawing a blank. Congrats to a good man and a good friend
column4: Flake said. Kaine could help Clinton in Virginia
column5: a heavily contested swing state
column6: and choosing Kaine will not cost Democrats a seat in the Senate
column7: where Republicans now hold a majority. Virginia's Democratic governor
column8: Terry McAuliffe
column9: a close Clinton friend and ally
column10: will name a replacement for Kaine if he and Clinton win the White House.Some Democrats who know Kaine well dismissed fears that he lacks the toughness to stand up to Republican attacks
column11: given how deftly Trump chewed up ""low-energy"" Jeb Bush and ""little Marco"" Rubio in the Republican primaries.    ""It's not the Donald Trump sledgehammer. But he's not a shrinking violet
column13: a former chief of staff to Democrat Mark Warner
column14: the senior U.S. senator from Virginia.    Albee
column15: who has watched Kaine up close over the years
column17: ""I wouldn't mistake a thoughtful and genial disposition for an inability to really forcefully articulate differences.""Kaine has good relations with senators from the opposing party
column18: according to senior Senate Republican congressional aides. One aide speculated Kaine would be effective in reaching out to congressional Republicans if he becomes vice president
column19: a role that Vice President Joe Biden has played for Obama.Kaine
column20: a member of the Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees
column21: has been a leading voice calling for a formal authorization of war against the Islamic State militant group. He played an important role in securing congressional review of the 2015 international deal on Iran's nuclear program
column22: although he eventually backed it.He has a track-record of backing liberal causes such as ending across-the-board automatic budget cuts and providing a pathway to citizenship to millions of undocumented immigrants.       Kaine
column23: a Catholic who became fluent in Spanish speaker while serving as a missionary in Honduras
column24: has expressed personal opposition to abortion
column25: but has a public record in support of abortion rights. (Additional reporting by Richard Cowan in Washington and Luciana Lopez in New York; Editing by Leslie Adler)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN1022ES	Trump pulls nearly even with Clinton after Republican convention: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has pulled nearly even with Democratic rival Hillary Clinton for the first time since May
column2: according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll taken over the course of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland this week.The July 18-22 national online poll found that 41 percent of likely voters supported Clinton
column3: while 38 percent supported Trump. Given the poll's credibility interval of about 4 percentage points
column4: Trump and Clinton should be considered to be about even in the race.MORE ELECTION 2016 COVERAGE:

column1: Commentary: Can Roger Ailes help Trump win like he helped Nixon in 1968?Sanders says would prefer Elizabeth Warren over Kaine as vice presidential pickObama's half-brother says he will vote for TrumpJust before Republicans opened the convention on Monday
column2: Trump had trailed Clinton by nearly 10 percentage points in the poll.

column1: The New York businessman-turned-politician formally accepted the Republican nomination for the Nov. 8 presidential election during a convention at which the party at times struggled to show unity.The week started with a dustup between convention leaders and delegates who wanted to change the party's rules to derail Trump's nomination. Later in the week
column2: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas
column3: who dropped out of the nomination race in May
column4: refused to endorse Trump in a prime-time speech.Yet
column5: on the final night of the convention
column6: Republicans gave Trump a standing ovation as he pledged to take back a country that he said is plagued by crime
column7: terrorism and ineffective leadership.

column1: Party conventions are partly meant to introduce the candidate to the country
column2: and nominees tend to get a boost in opinion polls afterward. In 2012
column3: then-Republican nominee Mitt Romney rose by about 5 percentage points in the Reuters/Ipsos poll after his party's convention.Clinton
column4: who is expected to be formally nominated by her party at its convention in Philadelphia next week
column5: has led Trump most of the year in the poll.

column1: The last time Trump drew about even with Clinton was in mid-May
column2: after his last two rivals for the Republican nomination dropped out of the race and party leaders started to get behind his campaign.The Reuters/Ipsos poll was conducted in English in all 50 states with 1
column3: 036 likely voters. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-women-idUSKCN1030NM	Women in male-dominated career fields watch a unique U.S. presidential campaign	"
By Alex Dobuzinskis
| LOS ANGELES
LOS ANGELES Dr. Linda Liau works with the precision of a master
column2: peering into a patient's head with magnifying loupes as she removes a brain tumor.When Liau was called into an emergency room as a surgeon more than 20 years ago to help treat a car crash victim
column3: another member of the medical team assumed she was a nurse.Even today
column4: the 49-year-old neurosurgeon sometimes gets a surprised reaction from new patients who were expecting a man. Such an assumption is common in career fields dominated by men.Neurosurgery
column5: welding
column6: venture capitalism
column7: construction
column8: film directing and the electrical trade - these are six jobs where U.S. women have made inroads but are still vastly outnumbered.And one position
column10: has never been filled by a woman. With presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton seeking to become the first to break that barrier
column11: several women in career fields made up mostly of men told Reuters that they saw her candidacy as significant.""I think ultimately the goal would be to be gender-blind completely
column12: so the fact that we're even talking about having a female president as a novelty is
column18: has often been reminded of her gender. Early in her career
column19: the reminders were pet names such as ""sweetheart"" and ""honey."" Now
column20: she can rarely shake the sense that she is outnumbered.""I eat lunch alone
column21: White said. ""I don't have people to relate to at work. ""Don't get me wrong
column22: I identify more with the guys
column25: I'm just a girl.""Wearing a hard hat
column26: White passes under heavy steel beams
column27: walking along the commuter train tracks she is helping build in her working-class neighborhood in southern Los Angeles.

column1: Welder Darlene Thompson
column3: is also no stranger to the construction site
column4: or to the hostility that she says women often encounter in the field. These days
column5: she teaches others as an instructor at Los Angeles Trade Technical College. In a heavy coat and blue gloves
column6: she looks from under her helmet at the white-hot flame of a welding torch. It was a fight to learn these skills. More than a decade ago
column7: when she began receiving job training as a welfare recipient
column8: Thompson had to argue for the chance to study welding. Public assistance administrators wanted to push her toward cosmetology or culinary arts
column9: she said. Thompson did not say how she would cast her ballot in November but said she would not vote for Clinton just because the candidate is a woman.Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's slogan has resonated with her.

column1: When they talk about 'Let's make America great again
column2: '"" Thompson said
column3: ""what I think of is the companies in Detroit
column4: the automotive industry going back to Detroit and giving back jobs.""A well-paid job as an electrician has opened up opportunities for Hannah Cooper
column5: 28. For one thing
column6: she was able to buy a house in the expensive Los Angeles real estate market.Sometimes
column7: she will encounter someone on a construction site who knows her mother
column8: Kelly Cooper
column9: who also was an electrician. ""Everyone remembers her because there's only a few women
column10: Cooper said.Kelly Cooper began as an apprentice in 1975.""You have to have thick skin to be anyone in the trade
column11: she said. ""To be a woman in the trade
column12: you have to have a particularly thick skin.""

column1: She is now director of construction for the Los Angeles Department of General Services.Eva Ho
column3: is a woman working in the technology field
column4: which is unusual enough. But she is also a venture capitalist
column5: which is rarer still.""In some ways the V.C. career has really been an old boys club
column6: and it's been dominated by white men for the last three or four decades
column7: Ho said. A graduate of Harvard and Cornell
column8: Ho said she was drawn to work in technology because of its ability to drive social change. But she came late to it
column9: never having used a computer until college.For the Burtons
column10: who work together as filmmakers through their company Five Sisters Productions
column11: their career had its seeds in their childhood as the daughters of a writer and a former professional musician. Both parents were feminists who thought their five daughters could do anything
column14: producer and actor. Now the possibility of a female president could help create more opportunities for women
column15: she said. ""Having a woman president opens up the presidency for girls
column17: ""and it will shift the perception for boys of what girls can do.""  (Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis; Editing by Lisa Von Ahn)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-orban-idUSKCN1030GN	Hungary's Orban likes what he hears of 'valiant' Trump's security plans	"
By Marton Dunai
| BUDAPEST

BUDAPEST Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban on Saturday said Donald Trump had proposed security policies that Europe should take to heart to solve a security crisis he blames on uncontrolled immigration.Speaking at a summer university in Baile Tusnad
column2: Romania
column3: the Hungarian leader tied increased security threats to increased migration and cited Trump's proposals at the Republican National Convention to combat terrorism.Orban is one of Europe's most outspoken politicians and has in the past upset fellow members of the European Union over policy.Most recently he has taken a tough stance on Europe's  migrant crisis
column4: objecting to EU resettlement plans and calling for a razor wire fence to be built along his country's southern border.Trump accepted the Republican nomination for president on Thursday with a speech that outlined an increased intelligence effort
column5: an end to a ""failed policy of nation-building and regime change"" and a total suspension of immigration from states ""compromised by terrorism.""He wants a wall to be built along the U.S. border with Mexico.Orban sought to buttress his own security proposals with Trump's points.""I am not a Donald Trump campaigner
column6: he said in the televised speech. ""I never thought I would ever entertain the thought that
column7: of the open options
column8: he (Trump) would be better for Europe and for Hungary.

column1: But I listened to the candidate and I must tell you he made three proposals to combat terrorism. And as a European I could have hardly articulated better what Europe needs.""Orban has accused the EU of weakness in the face of a what he sees as a fundamental threat from more than a million migrants who arrived on the continent last year
column2: with hundreds of thousands following them this year.For the most part
column3: the migrants are fleeing the war in Syria.European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has called Orban ""Viktator"" - a pun on Viktor and dictator - as a way of putting down the Hungarian's views.

column1: But Orban also has supporters. Slovak premier Robert Fico
column2: joined Orban's court challenge of the EU's mandatory migrant resettlement quotas.EXPORTING DEMOCRACY

column1: Tapping into Trump's proposals to create ""the best intelligence-gathering organisation in the world
column2: Orban said that Europe too needs to create a network of national intelligence agencies that ranks with the world's best.

column1: He then took aim at some of his EU colleagues.""The second thing
column2: said this valiant American presidential candidate
column3: is to abandon the policy of exporting democracy. I could not have said it more precisely.""Orban said Western countries acted recklessly to remove the undemocratic but stable regimes in Libya
column4: Syria and Iraq without guaranteeing stability in the aftermath
column5: exposing Europe to a mass wave of migration.Worse
column6: he said
column7: instead of supporting the regimes that try to control the civil-war-torn countries in North Africa and the Middle East
column8: Europe criticises them for democratic shortfalls.""If we keep prioritising democracy over stability in regions where we are unlikely to succeed with that
column10: not democracy."" (Reporting by Marton Dunai Editing by Jeremy Gaunt)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-alaska-court-abortion-idUSKCN10304K	Alaska's top court rejects parental notice for abortions	"
By Eric M. Johnson
| SEATTLE
SEATTLE An Alaska law requiring doctors to notify the parents of girls under the age of 18 seeking an abortion violates the state's constitution and cannot be enforced
column2: the state's top court ruled on Friday.The 4-1 decision marks a long-awaited victory for Planned Parenthood and other abortion-rights advocates in Alaska who argued the 2010 law violates the privacy of pregnant teens.It also comes on the heels of the U.S. Supreme Court decision to strike down a Texas abortion law imposing strict regulations on doctors and facilities in the strongest endorsement of abortion rights in America in more than two decades.A woman's right to abortion was established in the court's landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade decision
column3: but several states have tried to restrict access to abortion through their own laws.

column1: In Alaska
column2: Planned Parenthood and doctors argued that the notification law was particularly threatening to vulnerable teens who live in abusive homes.Justice Daniel Winfree
column3: writing for the majority
column4: said that the notification law's ""discriminatory barrier to those minors seeking to exercise their fundamental privacy right to terminate a pregnancy violates Alaska's equal protection guarantee.""Another justice
column5: Dana Fabe
column6: in a concurring opinion
column7: wrote that ""the Alaska Constitution permits a parental notification law
column8: but not one that contains provisions that are among the most restrictive of any state's notification laws.""

column1: The office of Alaska's Attorney General did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Alaska's law required 48-hour advance notice to parents before a physician may terminate a minor's pregnancy
column2: though it allowed a minor to seek a judge's permission to bypass the notice process and granted an exception for medical emergencies.

column1: The law took effect in 2010 after a Superior Court ruled that the state had an interest in promoting communication between a pregnant girl and her family.Christine Charbonneau
column2: president and CEO of Planned Parenthood of the Great Northwest and the Hawaiian Islands
column3: said in a statement that ""We all want teens to be safe - and the sad truth is that some teens live in dangerous homes and can't go to their parents."" (Reporting by Eric M. Johnson in Seattle; Editing by Mary Milliken)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-kaine-idUSKCN103012	Kaine's crime-busting past may hurt Clinton's outreach to blacks	"
By James Oliphant
| RICHMOND
column2: Va.

column1: RICHMOND
column2: Va. Democrat Hillary Clinton's pick of Tim Kaine as her vice presidential running mate could hamper her efforts to reach out to African-American voters because of Kaine's past embrace of crime-fighting strategies that have driven up the U.S. prison population and are unpopular in the black community.The now-defunct Project Exile that Kaine backed was so unusual it was championed by Republicans and Democrats alike and by both the top U.S. gun lobby group and gun-control advocates. But the federal program launched in 1997 in Richmond
column3: Virginia
column4: was also criticized at the time as a racially biased initiative that condemned young black men to lengthy prison terms.Clinton has come under fire herself from black activists for her past support for tough-on-crime policies of the 1990s now blamed for a surge in U.S. prison population and heightened tensions between law enforcement and black communities.One of her fundraisers got disrupted earlier this year by activists who asked her to ""apologize for mass incarceration."" Clinton named Kaine as her running mate late on Friday
column5: making what is considered a safe choice for her battle against Republican presidential rival Donald Trump.As Richmond mayor from 1998 to 2001
column6: Kaine
column8: was a vocal supporter of Project Exile
column9: crediting it with reducing the city's murder rate.Its goal was to literally live up to its name by making illegal gun possession a federal
column12: which allowed prosecutors to send convicted felons
column14: to a distant federal penitentiary for at least five years.Sam Sinyangwe
column16: a group focused on curtailing police violence
column17: said Kaine's choice could exacerbate Clinton's problems rallying support of African-Americans

column1: To select somebody like (Kaine) is not a sign of good leadership potential in a president
column2: Sinyangwe said.Nicole Lee
column3: a civil-rights lawyer and activist in Washington
column4: D.C. who is African-American
column5: also expressed concern.""Project Exile broke black families
column6: she said. ""This is not a benign thing to be for. These measures were not used against white kids in the suburbs with guns
column7: they were used against black kids in the cities.""DRAMATIC TIMES

column1: To defeat Trump in the Nov. 8 presidential election
column2: Clinton needs high turnout among blacks and other minority voters to offset Trump's popularity among white voters.During the 1990s
column3: she supported tough-on-crime initiatives backed by her husband
column4: former President Bill Clinton
column5: but now vows to ""end the era of mass incarceration.""Her campaign is trying to walk a political tightrope after the killings of two black men by police and the shooting deaths of police officers in Texas and Louisiana. She has offered support for the Black Lives Matter movement
column6: while also strongly condemning the killings of police officers.Officials who were in Richmond during Kaine's mayoral tenure believe the community
column7: ravaged by the crack-cocaine epidemic and an escalating murder rate
column8: had to take dramatic steps. Amy Dudley
column9: a spokeswoman in Kaine's Senate office
column10: said the senator stood by the program
column11: believing that it reduced gun violence.

column1: Jerry Oliver
column2: the police chief at the time and an African-American
column3: said the program focused on black communities out of necessity. ""We had to be where the problems were
column4: he said. The National Rifle Association
column5: the nation's biggest gun lobby
column6: was an early proponent of Project Exile as was the gun-control advocacy group Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence. As Richmond's first white mayor in more than a decade
column7: Kaine was widely credited for helping to bridge racial divisions in the city
column8: but Project Exile drew fire from defense lawyers and community advocates who argued that the program unfairly targeted African-Americans.Kevin Ring
column9: vice president of Families Against Mandatory Minimums
column10: a Washington advocacy group lobbying against federal sentencing minimums
column13: will have to demonstrate to black voters that he has ""evolved"" on the issue. ""There are some that will be bothered. There will be questions
column14: Ring said.Kaine supports legislation that would roll back some mandatory minimum federal sentences and give judges more discretion
column15: although his office says he still supports firm sentences for illegal gun possession. Kaine's backing of Project Exile also makes him odd bedfellows with Trump
column16: who has made law and order a central theme of his candidacy. Trump has called for the program's revival and his campaign website said it was ""tremendous."" (Additional reporting by Alana Wise and Emily Flitter; Editing by Caren Bohan and Tomasz Janowski)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trumpuniversity-idUSKCN10211J	Judge tentatively rejects bid to toss Trump University lawsuit	"
By Marty Graham
| SAN DIEGO

SAN DIEGO A U.S. judge on Friday tentatively rejected Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's bid to dismiss a lawsuit by Trump University students who said they were defrauded through its real-estate seminars.U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel in San Diego told a hearing he would take under consideration arguments on both sides in the case and issue a written ruling in the coming weeks. The 2013 lawsuit
column2: one of three over the defunct Trump University venture
column3: was filed on behalf of students who paid up to $35
column4: 000 to learn Trump's real estate investing ""secrets"" from his ""hand-picked"" instructors.  The plaintiffs have sought class-action status.The cases against Trump University have regularly cropped up during the presidential campaign. Trump was roundly criticized in May when he accused Curiel
column5: who is of Mexican descent
column6: of being biased against him because of the candidate's pledge to build a border wall between the United States and Mexico. Curiel
column7: who was born in Indiana
column8: is presiding over two of the cases
column9: with one set for trial in late November. A separate lawsuit by New York's attorney general is pending in that state.

column1: Trump's lawyers say Curiel should toss the 2013 California lawsuit on the grounds that the New York real estate mogul
column2: though personally involved in developing the concept and curriculum
column3: relied on other executives to manage Trump University by the time the plaintiffs purchased their seminars.""By 2007
column4: his involvement was fairly minimal. He was not the person running this company. He founded it
column5: he established it and he went off and let other people run it. It's like any other celebrity endorsement
column6: Trump attorney Daniel Petrocelli said during the hearing.

column1: Trump's lawyers claim references in marketing materials to ""secrets
column2: ""hand-picked"" instructors or ""university"" were mere sales ""puffery."" According to the defense
column3: there is no evidence Trump intended to defraud students.Lawyers for the students say the wealthy developer conducted the marketing for Trump University more than anyone else
column4: starring in and approving promotional materials.They claim Trump University instructors were high-pressure sales people
column5: not ""professors and adjunct professors"" as Trump touted
column6: and that New York authorities told Trump back in 2005 to stop calling his unaccredited venture a university.

column1: Somehow
column2: belligerence trumps substance
column3: plaintiff's attorney Jason Forge said. ""If we say it loud enough
column4: forcefully enough
column5: it becomes true. Well
column6: it doesn't.""Trump owned 92 percent of Trump University and had control over all major decisions
column7: plaintiffs' court papers say. (Additional reporting by Karen Freifeld and Dan Whitcomb; Editing by Tom Brown and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-congress-opioids-obama-idUSKCN1022KW	Obama signs into law opioid addiction bill to protect newborns	"
By Duff Wilson
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON President Barack Obama on Friday signed into law a measure that pledges greater efforts to protect drug-dependent newborns and assist their parents.The Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act also stresses drug treatment and overdose prevention to help stanch the nation's heroin and opioid drug epidemic.Obama said in a statement that 78 Americans die from opioid overdose every day
column2: and noted that the legislation included only modest steps to address the epidemic.""I am deeply disappointed that Republicans failed to provide any real resources for those seeking addiction treatment to get the care that they need
column3: Obama said. ""In fact
column4: they blocked efforts by Democrats to include $920 million in treatment funding.""The bill was passed nearly unanimously by both the House of Representatives and the Senate.Efforts to enforce provisions to protect newborns and help their parents come in response to a Reuters investigation last year titled ""Helpless & Hooked.""The new law requires that the federal government and every state follow a 2003 law that was routinely ignored. That law called on states to require hospitals and social services to report
column5: track and assist drug-dependent newborns and their families.

column1: Reuters found that no more than nine states were following that requirement. Most children born to addicted mothers
column2: including many mothers who were taking prescribed methadone
column3: were not being reported by hospitals as required by law. Often
column4: that was because medical workers feared involving child protective services
column5: as the existing law requires. When cases were reported to social services
column6: Reuters found
column7: efforts to protect the child and help the parents often were limited.The failures came at a cost. Reuters found more than 110 babies since 2010 died under preventable circumstances after being sent home to families ill-equipped to care for them. Experts said far more children have likely died but gone uncounted.The new law promises a non-punitive approach that includes ""safe care plans"" aimed at keeping newborns at home with their parents
column8: who will receive additional help.

column1: This is a step forward for vulnerable babies who
column2: due to an opioid dependency
column3: will begin their lives facing enormous challenges
column4: said Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania
column5: the ranking Democrat on the Senate subcommittee on children and families. ""Reuters' initial reporting shined a light on a darkness that had enveloped far too many lives. There is much more work to do but this is a genuine step forward.""Representative John Kline
column6: a Minnesota Republican who chairs the House Committee on Education and the Workforce
column7: which initiated the measure
column8: said it will track state actions.""These reforms are an important part of our broader efforts to combat the nation's opioid epidemic and provide these vulnerable families a better chance at a brighter future
column10: the latest year with nationwide hospital reporting
column12: 315 babies were diagnosed with newborn drug withdrawal syndrome
column13: a five-fold increase from a decade earlier.

column1: Reuters found that one drug-dependent baby was born on average every 19 minutes in the United States. Some suffer shaking
column2: crying and feeding problems as they battle withdrawal.Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon
column3: the ranking Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee
column4: said the broader addiction law was ""no more than a half measure"" without more funding. Wyden has co-sponsored a measure setting aside money for substance abuse treatment for parents in danger of losing their children. It passed the House but stalled in the Senate.Jim Greenwood
column5: a former Pennsylvania congressman who championed the 2003 law
column6: said the deaths Reuters revealed represent ""a national disgrace and glaring failure at the federal
column7: state and local level to implement Plans of Safe Care for infants."" Greenwood
column8: now president of a Washington
column10: applauded the new measure ""to improve the health and safety of these babies and their families.""Stephen Patrick
column11: an assistant professor of pediatrics at Vanderbilt University and leading researcher on the condition
